text: DIRK GINADER: Hi.
I'm Dirk.

I work as a
prototyper at Google.

And I want to talk to
you today about how

to teach your browser
some new tricks.

Or rather, as I wanted
to say firsthand,

teach your old dog some new
tricks, 'cause they can.

So, about four
years ago there was

a lot of discussion about
a thing called Longdesc.

And at that point, the HTML5
working group basically
decided to get rid of it.

And then there was a massive
shit storm that fell on.

And there was lots and lots
of discussion on what to do.

So, Bruce Lawson, lovely
fellow, wrote an epic blog post

which was followed by an
even more epic common thread

in which things were mentioned
of how we can basically

go ahead and save or make
it better, or get rid of it.

And so, first of all, who of you
know what Longdesc actually is?
That is not very many people.
And that is for a good reason.

Because it's terribly,
terribly underused.

So, what Longdesc
is-- and there's

links on all of those
slides, by the way.

And you can download
the slide deck later on.

The link to the slide deck
is on the very last one.
So don't cheat.

So, Longdesc is a little
attribute on an image.

And instead of
using the Alt Text--

and who of you know
what an Alt Text is?
Many more people.
Excellent.

So instead of using, or
actually additionally

to using the Alt
Text, you can go ahead

and define a whole page
to describe that one image

that you're showing there,
which is actually something that

is generally useful for
very complex images.

So the example I show
here is basically image,

and long description is
pointing to URL, just the way
it should be.

Now, something that is also
defined in DW3C standard
is that it must be discoverable.

And it must be discoverable
by automatically--

I'm just reading
what it says here.

It must be simple
for a user agent

to automatically discover
a description provided

for a given image,
which is something
that hardly anyone does.

But some of them do or
did-- I mean, like, undid.

And then the other
thing is, a user

should be able to
determine if there

is a subscription available
for a given image.

That is something that
not one of them did.

So basically there's
this hidden little gem
of information on that image.
And nobody knows about it.

So, I was approached
by somebody.
[LAUGHTER]
I had to, John.

I was approached by John about
what we can do about this.

I think we met at CSUN, or
was it at the Open Web Camp?
I can't even remember.
It was--

JOHN FOLIOT: I had
a beer in my hand.
DIRK GINADER: Yes!
Yes.
Oh, yeah.

Lucy, for your information,
it's an animated GIF of John
holding up a beer.
It's fantastic.

The link is john.
folio. awesome. pose.

So, there was months and
months being followed

by a discussion on
what we could do.

And I eventually give in and
wrote a little jQuery plug-in

that-- you can tell the link
is up there-- which basically

allowed somebody
who runs a website

and has Longdesc attributes on
their images to expose those

to people without
assistive technology.

So for the first time--
oh not for the first time,

but for the first
time that I quite

like the way it did it--
was there was suddenly

a way that people who
don't have, let's say,

a screen reader, who exposes
those information to them,
were actually able to see that.
And this is how it looked like.
So, this is an example page.

I stole this from
a WebAIM back then.

They don't actually
have that anymore.

What it does is that
image that you just saw

disappear-- this
one-- has suddenly
a little icon on the bottom.

And when you hover over,
or when you tap on it,

it says, "click for
more information."
And then you do.

And then the content
of the URL that

is given in the
Longdesc attribute

is loaded via AGIX onto
that page, onto the image,
and shown.

So you can actually
read it and consume it,

and get information
out of there.

And compared to that image
that you saw in the example,

that written information
is actually pure gold.

It makes much more sense to
me than the image itself.

So I was really
happy about this.

And then John, again,
went ahead and posted it,
I think, basically everywhere.

And there was lots of
discussion on what to do.

And everybody was kind of
excited about, oh yeah,
we should do something.
We should do something.

And, there wasn't really
anything done, was there?

But I think it ended up
that W3C did eventually
get back the attribute.

I don't claim that I had
to do anything with that.

However, my little plug-in
that I wrote-- this

is the JavaScript
code that drives it.

It's completely
irrelevant right now.

But it should just say that it's
a very, very small code that

had very big impact and
was very easy to write.

And this is what it
does to the browser.

So what you can see is that it's
really just adding a little DOM

node, a little button
on top of the image that

says, "click here for more
information about this image."

And when you click on it,
it makes an AGIX request,

adds another information,
sets focus on it.

So it's actually nicely
expressible to people

who do rely on assistive
technology as well.

So, some browsers don't even
work for that, worked as well.
Very happy about this.

And then something
else happened.

And it has been bugging me
for the last four years.

Again, John handed
me to Charles.

Charles will give a talk
right after this one
in the other room.
AUDIENCE: This room.
DIRK GINADER: In this room?
OK.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
DIRK GINADER: Never mind.
Next talk-- you should see it.
That's great.

So Charles has been working on
a browser extension for Chrome--
not for Chrome.
For Opera.

He was working for
Opera back then,
and had this little extension.
And it worked.

And I was asked to, I think,
make another extension

for another browser
or something.
And I just couldn't do it.

This is how the extension
essentially looked like.

You basically had to
click on the top right,

and then it would show the
image again and some text on it.

And I liked the idea
that I did that.
And I couldn't really do it.

Because I find it
looks dreadful.
And the code was terrible.

And I looked at
documentation on how

you write extensions
for other browsers.
And it's dreadful.

And every browser
does it differently.
It was painful.

So while I was
procrastinating on this,

Patrick [? Lowky ?] did the
same extension for Firefox.

I think there it
actually integrated
in the Context menus.

You had to right-click
on an image,

hoping it may or may
not have Longdesc.
Then it might be there.

And you clicked on it, and
would then show the text.

It wasn't really
much better either.

However, I was still
procrastinating.

And again, while I
was procrastinating,
my good friend-- where is he?
Oh, he left.
Never mind.

Dennis Lembrecht did a
blog post, a nice summary

of basically everything that is
right or wrong about Longdesc.
Most of it was wrong.
Most of it was right.
There's a lot of information.
There's a link to this article.

If you want to know
anything about Longdesc,
Read it up there.

It's rather complete
list of everything

that's terrible at Longdesc, all
about what went bad about it.

So, four years I've
been actively very

heavily, and in my own sweat
sitting there procrastinating

over not doing
anything about this.
And then I went to CSUN again.

And at CSUN, Joe Dalton
spoke to me, saying hey,

I saw this-- I know,
it was John again.

John handed my plug-in
that I wrote four years ago
to Joe Dalton.

And he actually
was the first one

who got excited about Longdesc
in the last four years.
And he did something amazing.
He wrote something for himself.

I think it's basically a mix of
what Carl did and what I did.

And he wrote an
extension for WordPress.

And because of the unique
position that Joe is in,

he managed to get
this into WordPress.

So basically if you want to
use Longdesc in WordPress,

and if you write
the text for it,

then WordPress will very
beautifully expose it to you,

by showing this little
button under an image.

And if you would
click on it, you

would see again the content
of this Longdesc image.

This is the first time
that actually Longdesc

has a platform that is bigger
than, let's say, the five

examples I can find
on the internet.

Because by default, WordPress
would actually support it.

So, again, after four years
of active procrastination,

I was suddenly feeling maybe
I should have done something
four years ago.

However, what basically kept me
from doing anything back then

was not just that I was
basically a lazy bastard,

but also that writing an
extension for one browser
didn't quite get me.

Because I've been
building websites.

And I've been building
websites in a way
so every browser can use them.

What the hell is the point
about writing an extension
that one browser can use?

So then, I really stumbled
over-- how's it called?
Crossrider.

And Crossrider-- I only saw
this link, and I saw this text,
and I was like, whoa!
Yes.

It announces that I can
create cross browser extension
for every browser in minutes.

And that was triggering
all the buttons

that I needed to
basically say, yeah, sure.
I try that.
Oh also, it says it's free.
[LAUGHTER]
Yes.

And it powers lots and lots
of insulation apparently.

So obviously I
registered very quickly.

And then I ended on this
page, where it tells me

that I should go ahead and
create a new extension.
So I did.

And it welcomes me to
the Developer Dashboard.

And it tells me what I
can do in actually rather
nice, simple words.
So I'm not scared away.
And I say, start coding.
And then I'm here.

And right away, I found
this very well-hidden--

that's why I have this massive
button and massive arrow
showing this teeny-tiny button.

It tells me that I can
upload existing code.

So, of course I just went
ahead and downloaded that code

I haven't touched in
four years from GitHub,
and uploaded it there.
And then I started reading docs.

Of course, you start
reading the docs

after you did something
first, of course.
So I have my code up there.
This is the code, by the way.

You can still see that
it's still version 1.0.

It hasn't been
touched in four years.
And it's suddenly up there.
And it's fantastic.
So, this is how it looks like.
You click there.

It wants you to
select your files.
And then they're there.

And then, having looked at
the documentation afterwards,

I found that there's
basically two important files.

And that is the one thing I
found in the last four years

when I was looking
at how to write

browser extensions for one
or more browsers-- basically

that's the one thing
that is basically

the same thing in
every documentation

for a specific
browser extension.

There's always a foreground and
a background JavaScript file.

Well, the foreground
JavaScript file

is the one that will
actually be executed
in the context of the page.

So it's like you just
add your own JavaScript
file to somebody else's page.

I quite like that
idea, because that
sounds like hacking something.

And then there's the
background JavaScript file,

which is the one
that runs constantly

while the browser is running,
and is able to absorb something

like clicks on a button
in the Chrome UI.

I didn't really need it at
point, so I just ignored it.

So I went ahead and made that
foreground JavaScript file--

it's called Extension
JavaScript file here,

because they abstracted away
so it works for everybody.

So I went ahead and included my
Longdesc JavaScript extension

code, which is just one
JavaScript file, and the CSS

that's needed to make
it all look nice,
loaded that in the extension JS.

So what it does-- quick
information beforehand.

What Crossrider does is it
will load jQuery for you.
Just assume it's already there.

And then it will fire the
app API dot Ready function.

It will pass pass
in a dollar, which

is your reference to
the latest jQuery.

It takes care of it
for you, thank God.

And then it can
use an app API dot

resources dot Include
CSS, which will load

the resources that you added
by uploading them here.

And they will live inside
of the extension code.

So whenever somebody's coming
and installs to the extension,

that file will be
in their browsers.
You don't have to host it.
You don't have to care about it.
It's been loaded.

And then, I went ahead
and initialized that code

I last initialized
four years ago

by just calling the
jQuery extension.
And then I-- oh, yeah.

There's one more thing that I
added because I work for Google

and I work specifically
for Google Analytics.

So when I saw in
the documentation

that there is a ready-made
Google Analytics

tag that I can just use,
that was first thing
I did-- data nerd that I am.

So, there's of course also some
Google Analytics code in there.
So I can track whatever happens.
And it's very interesting.
So, one extra thing.

After I tried it for the first
time, my images didn't show up.

So I had to read
more documentation.
Oh, man.

And I found out
that I couldn't just

reference a file, an image,
by just using it [INAUDIBLE].

No, I have to use
a special protocol.

It's called a Resource
Image Protocol.

It's basically dot HTTP, but for
local files in the extension.

So I had to make this one
change for that one image
that I'm using there.

And then I went to click
Install the Staging Extension.

Now that was something that
was very fascinating to me.

Because it basically
promises me that I

can install that
extension locally and then

keep developing the
extension online.
Sounded like voodoo to me.
I liked it.
So I downloaded the extension.

And it's basically
just a zip file.
So you unzip that file.

And then it tells
you to go-- I'm
using Chrome for development.
It doesn't have to be Chrome.

But they use it for
all their defaults.
So I just did the same thing.

And I went to the Extensions tab
and turned on Developer Mode.

And that revealed the Load
Unpacked extension button.

So I unpacked the zip file that
I downloaded, navigated to it.

And as you can see
already, it's like full
of HTML and JavaScript file.
Don't even bother looking at it.

Because the stage
extension doesn't actually
contain your code.

What they do so you
can keep working on it

is they just link to their own
server where your code lives.
So you can keep working there.

And it will just load your
code for the time being

while they're developing
from their servers.

So you just need this one
stub to start working.

So you select the
folder, and whoa.

There is an extension
installed in my browser.

It has the name of the
extension that I built.

And it looks like
it could be working.

So, I go ahead and
go into the code

and add a little console lock
so I know something's happening.
And I tried that.
And it didn't.

And then, I stopped reading the
docs and went to Stack Overflow

instead, which is the
better docs for everything.

And they told me that you should
definitely first hit the Reload
button on the browser.
Because, even though--
--yeah.
Duh.
[LAUGHTER]

So I did that, and it
turns out it works.

Then I did also another error,
because I was just being quick.

And I had one example that I
had downloaded from WebAIM.

And I had just dragged
in the browser.
And it wouldn't work either.

So, of course you have
to run your demo code

on actually HTTP server,
because the File Column
Protocol doesn't work.
So you have to be an HTTP.

So, whoever hasn't
done that or maybe

doesn't have like [? Map ?]
or something installed,

there's a teeny tiny
one-liner Python

that creates an HTTP server
that you can beautifully
use just for stuff like that.

You just navigate on your
terminal to your folder.

And you type Python dash
[? m ?] Simple HTTP server.

And it creates a server
that runs on Port 8000.
And then I could run my codes.
And it worked.
And it actually got my locks.

And I saw my little
icon turn up there.
And it's beautiful.

So, after this-- at it literally
took, like, half an hour maybe.

And there was a lot of back
and forth and stack overflow,

and me being already close to
starting procrastinating again.
So it actually worked.

So, being excited about
this, I started digging
in the documentation.

And I was quite stunned by
the beautiful amount of stuff
that is in there.

Being a browser extension, so
basically being a the browser,

rather than just a website
that runs in the browser,

your codes has suddenly a much
higher status of, oh I can do
this, rather than, no I can't.

So suddenly things work
like, cross domain requests.

Whoa, I can load
data from everywhere.

Which was one of things
that kind of made me sad

when I built the original
Longdesc extension, is

that the link in
the Longdesc has
to be in the very same server.

Otherwise of course I
couldn't [INAUDIBLE] request.

And everything would
fail and look terrible.
I can work around this.

I haven't done this,
yet, of course.

But it's totally
going to be in v2.
That's a joke.
Everybody knows I won't.
[LAUGHTER]

The other thing that
will totally be in v2

is a browser button,
which I don't have to yet.

Somebody have problem--
at least seen that,

if you have quite a few
extensions installed.

This is the profile
here, by the way.
I installed everything.
It's a blank profile.

Because my view profile is like
all the way up to the left.

I have so many
extensions in there.

And everybody has their
own little button.
A nice little graphic in there.
I don't have that yet.
But I will.

And I will do
something of the like,

as Charles did back in
his very first extension.

I totally want to reveal
those Longdesc images.

Because if you go back to--
do you see this little icon
up there.

You probably don't,
because it's very small.

So, I know it's there
because I was looking for it.

If it would randomly pop up
on a page, I might not find.

So I totally want to
implement a little button.

And I click on it, it
will add massive red,

blinking, dash
outlines to the image.

So I can find if
something is there

and actually be
excited about it.
So I'm speaking massively fast.

If you have any
questions, go ahead
and interrupt me at any time.

Because I'm burning
through my slides here,

because I'm actually
excited about this.

By the way, did I
see- wait a second.

I'm not sure if you
actually saw this.

I'm going all the
way back right now.
Did you see this?
Read the text.
LUCY: I'm sorry. [INAUDIBLE]

DIRK GINADER: I'm going
to read it for Lucy.

It says, if you have working
code, you can simply upload it.
Yo, Karl!

Added this just
after he basically

put me on the spot
saying that I should
write an extension for him.

AUDIENCE: Did you add
that after he said that?
DIRK GINADER: Yes.
[LAUGHTER]

AUDIENCE: I saw that it reads
Jason, so I mean, you know.
DIRK GINADER: There you go.

AUDIENCE: You could totally
just take that and run with it.
DIRK GINADER: Yes.
Yes, you definitely can.

And you can actually
just call your API.

You don't even have to-- you
can reduce the amount of code
you need to write this.

Or you just go ahead and
write that little extension

that you wrote last night, and
just inject it into every page.
Should work just as well.

So, v2 is totally
going to happen.

And then, of course this is all
just code that I have locally.

So there's this Sync
with Production button.

And if you're proud
enough that it all works.

And you hit it,
and it allows you

to push a production,
or even better feeling,

it tells you that
it can roll back
from production, which is great.

And then, it just goes
in production mode,

and it tells me you
can't edit any more.
Kind of a bummer.

And then you realize, OK,
let's check the settings.

And this is where
it gets interesting.

Because there, you go ahead and
add a little bit of imagery,

so you can add a
nice little icon.

I'm terrible at this, so I
just did a little screen shot

from the image that it
shows on top of an image.

And it didn't really
fit in the square.
So I just made it.

And I wrote a little
Longdesc for the Longdesc.
And then I got excited.

Because it started
showing me download links.

And it tells me that there's
a page where I can just

point people to, and
it would automatically
detect their browser.
And they download my extension.
Oh my God.

And then even
better, there's a way

to directly export my extension
to the Chrome Web Store.

So until just recently--
and I used this before,
and now it's no longer there.
So I'm kind of bummed.

You could do the same
thing for Mozilla
on store, whatever it's called.

They have some problems
with it right now.

They promised me in
the discussion forum

yesterday that they were
going to add it back.

So I'm going to
promise you same thing.

You can export it
there, too, or you will.

But if you go ahead,
you can easily just

download the zip for
the Chrome Web Store,

and then log into your Google
Developer account, which

is just your regular
Google account on Chrome.

And there you can upload this
little zip that you just got.

And then, after some waiting--
it took me about an hour

or so before it was
public-- I saw this.
And I saw this before.
And I saw this in other people.

Look, my God, it's
a real extension.
It has real images.
People can install it.

I did this screen
shot yesterday.
You can see it's one user.
That's me.
[LAUGHTER]

I'm totally going to
rely on you to download,
so I'm going to count up.
This is the link.

I want at least, let's say,
20 more users in a year.

Because now, after
having installed this,
I can browse the web.

And this is the really
tough part right now.

I've been looking for examples
of pages that have Longdesc.

This ugly little thing is
actually one of the few
that still work.

Because there are
lists of examples.
And they are so old.
Most of them are broken.

But now, this is one of
the last ones around.
And this is how it looks before.
Now wait for it.

This is how it looks now after
installing the extension.
It's wonderful.
And you can click on it.

And it tells me, oh look,
there's more information.
And then there is.

That's the text hidden behind
in this tiny little Longdesc
description.
And I can read it.

And honestly it makes
more sense to me

than this, which makes
no sense to me at all.
All right.
So, thanks a lot.

This, by the way, is
my son and my dog.
They teach all kinds of tricks.

So I want you to go out
and teach your browsers
lots of new tricks.
Thanks a lot.
AUDIENCE: Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
